Pastore ⁎ Institute of Chemistry, University of Campinas, Monteiro Lobato St., 270, 13084-971 Campinas, SP, Brazil Institute of Chemistry University of Campinas Monteiro Lobato St., 270 Campinas SP 13084-971 Brazil ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract In this work, aluminum- and vanadium-modified magadiites with Si/Al=15 and Si/V=33 molar ratios were obtained by Seed Induced Crystallization (SIC) method and the solid was investigated in relation to its acidity. The catalysts were characterized using X-ray diffraction (XRD), inductively coupled plasma–atomic emission spectrometry (ICP–OES), solid state magic angle spinning nuclear magnetic resonance (MAS-NMR), temperature-programmed desorption of ammonia (NH3-TPD) and Fourier transformed infrared spectroscopy in situ (FTIR). Crystalline [Al]-and [V]-magadiites were successfully obtained in which metal ions were inserted in the structure of the solid in tetrahedral coordination. The acidities of [M]-magadiites were used in catalytic ethanol conversion monitored by in situ FTIR: ethylene (949cm−1) and acetaldehyde (1760–1730cm−1) were the products obtained. Keywords Ethanol conversion [Al]-magadiite [V]-magadiite Ethylene Acetaldehyde 1 Introduction The lamellar silicate magadiite is a member of the family of silicic acids, which also includes makatite, kanemite, octosilicate and kenyaite [1]. In spite of the fact that it was reported in the literature as early as 1967 [2], magadiite’s crystalline structure has not been determined yet [3]. The general formula of magadiite is Na2Si14O29(5–10)H2O and is formed by silicon atoms connected to four oxygen atoms; the tetrahedra share corners forming the lamella that characterize the solid [1,3–5]. The excess negative charge present on the surface is counterbalanced by hydrated sodium ions located in the interlayer spaces. Due to this arrangement, the lamella of this silicate displays three different silicon environments; Q2 ((O−/HO)2Si(OSi)2), Q3 ((O−/HO)Si(OSi)3) and Q4 (Si(OSi)4) sites. The silanol groups in magadiite surface are considered very weak Brønsted acid sites [6], however, the acidity of these materials may be improved by the isomorphous substitution of silicon atoms by trivalent atoms such as aluminum, creating a negative charge for each atom replaced [7–9]. Naturally, these negative charges are counterbalanced by compensation cations, generally Na+. When these ions are exchanged by H+, directly or by NH4 + ion-exchange followed by thermal treatment, Brønsted acid sites appear in the solid. In addition to its high ion exchange capacity, this silicate may also be used as precursor for obtaining other porous solids [10,11]. Superti et al. [8] studied the surface properties of [Al]-magadiite by direct and aluminum induced crystallization (AIC) methods. The authors observed that the direct synthesis, that is, addition of Al to the synthesis gel, resulted in amorphous or highly contaminated magadiite, whereas the Al-induced crystallization provided crystalline materials in shorter reaction time. Moura et al. [7] improved the Al-crystallization method by showing that is possible to insert aluminum into the framework of magadiite through the addition of seeds directly into the gel; this method was named Seed Induced Crystallization (SIC). SIC consists in the addition of the aluminum source in the synthesis gel of the reaction along with a small amount of crystals of siliceous magadiite. Crystallization is induced by the seeds and reduces the number of steps in the procedure, optimizing and simplifying the synthetic route. The addition of seed drives the synthesis to the desired phase and reduces the formation of impurities [12]. Ethanol dehydration has been performed over many catalysts such as zeolites, aluminas and heteropolyacids [13–17]. Ethanol dehydration can take place by two competitive paths accompanied by a side reaction (Reactions 1–3). (1) C 2 H 5 OH → C 2 H 4 +H 2 O (2) 2 C 2 H 5 OH → C 2 H 5 OC 2 H 5 +H 2 O (3) C 2 H 5 OH → CH 3 CHO+H 2 Reaction (1) is the intramolecular dehydration of ethanol to ethylene, which is the dominant product obtained at high temperatures while Reaction (2) is the intermolecular dehydration of ethanol to diethylether (DEE), which is the main product observed at low temperatures. Acetaldehyde can be obtained as the product of a side Reaction (3), at high temperatures. Ethanol can be dehydrated through an unimolecular pathway to generate ethylene or through a bimolecular route to produce DEE [14,18]. The mechanism for formation of DEE involves the adsorption of a molecule ethanol on a Brønsted acid site followed by the adsorption of a second molecule on the same acid site, thus forming an ethanol dimer. Dehydration of this dimer adsorbed form DEE and H2O and regenerates the site acid. Another mechanism involving DEE conversion includes adsorption of a molecule ethanol, followed by dehydration, forming ethoxy group which reacts with a second molecule of ethanol adsorbed, generating DEE. On the other hand, the desorption of ethoxy group generate ethylene. This product can also be an intermediate in dehydrating ethanol to ethylene. The selective oxidation of ethanol over vanadium silicate molecular sieves with MEL topology was investigated by Sivasanker et al. [19]. Acetaldehyde, DEE and ethylene were the main products obtained. It is important to mention that the nature of the active sites present control the selectivity of any specific product: V =O sites associated with extralattice and lattice vanadium is responsible for the formation of acetaldehyde and both V =O and VOSi associated with vanadium in the lattice are responsible for DEE formation. The dehydration of ethanol over H-FER, H-MFI, H-MOR, H-BEA and H-Y zeolites, silica-alumina and alumina was recently investigated by Phung et al. [15], who concluded that these zeolites (in these particular Si/Al molar ratios) are most active in the ethanol conversion to ethylene and DEE when compared to alumina and silica-alumina. The authors assigned their findings to the presence of Brønsted acid sites in zeolitic cavities and, mainly, the role of pore size and morphology—shape selectivity and confinement—as well as Al content. Silica alumina and alumina do not present cavities, therefore the effects observed in zeolites are not operative. Besides catalysts such as alumina and zeolites, the calcined hydrotalcite was also used in this reaction and DEE cracking. The study showed that the both reactions are catalyzed efficiently over all catalysts, except on calcined hydrotalcite. The last catalyst is weakly active in these reactions due its weak acidic, highlighting the role of acid sites for both reactions [14]. Ethanol dehydrogenation to acetaldehyde on metals supported on silica has been widely used [20], but highly dehydrated silica or silicalite-1 have also shown to be active [21,22] in that reaction. Silica surface is only slightly acidic due to the presence of silanols. The best results were obtained for silica treated at 897°C from reactions at temperatures above 277°C. To study the acid-base properties of highly dehydrated silica, NH3 and CO2-TPD were performed on the solids. For samples treated at high and low temperatures the desorption of NH3 and CO2 occurred at room temperature, indicating there is no acidic or basic sites on the silica surface and that, in this case, ethanol dehydrogenation is not catalyzed by acidic or basic sites. As the heating of silica at high temperatures causes condensation of silanol groups to form siloxane bridges (Reaction 4), the authors suggested that the active sites for the dehydrogenation of ethanol are the bridged oxygen atoms. (4) ≡ Si −OH + HO −Si ≡ → ≡ Si −O −Si ≡ +H 2 O Regarding the use of layered silicates in catalysis, montmorillonite was used in reactions such as benzophenone cyanotrimethysilylation with cyanotrimethylsilane over Sn-montmorillonite [23] and nitration of aromatic compounds on montmorillonite treated with phosphoric acid [24]. No other clays or layered silicates materials were found as acid catalysts.Taking all these facts into account, the aim of this work is to investigate the catalytic performance of [V]-and [Al]-magadiite on ethanol conversion reactions. To the best of our knowledge, conversion of ethanol over layered silicates has not been reported in the literature. The reactions were monitored using in situ FTIR of surface and gas phase at various reaction temperatures. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalysts preparation The lamellar [M]-magadiites were synthesized according to the SIC method described previously [7] with modifications. In order to obtain a material free of aluminum contamination, the sodium metasilicate was synthesized at laboratory by dispersing of the 0.1457mol of SiO2 in 250mL of a NaOH solution (0.2914mol), to obtain a gel with the Na:Si molar ratio was equal to 2:1. The mixture obtained was stirred and heated at 100°C for 24h. To the gel was added HNO3 until pH 10.4–10.6. The gel was aged during 4h at 74–76°C. Then Al[OCH(CH3)2]3 or VOSO4.4.2H2O was added to the gel to yield Si/Al=15 and Si/V=33 molar ratios and a small amount of siliceous magadiite, previously synthesized as described in literature [25], was added to the gel. The reactions were performed under argon atmosphere until transfer to autoclave. In order to obtain samples in the ammonium form, NH4 +-magadiite, NH4 +-[Al]- and NH4 +-[V]-magadiite, each sample was dispersed in 0.1molL−1 NH4Cl solution (1g of sample/0.1L of solution) [8]. This system was kept under magnetic stirring for 24h. After that, the solid was filtered and washed with deionized water until the supernatant tested negative for Cl− ions. This procedure was performed in triplicate for each sample. The treatment for NH4 + decomposition was carried out under the following conditions: the materials were heated at 5°Cmin−1 under argon atmosphere from room temperature to 450°C, temperature at which each sample was kept for 3h under O2 flow. The final samples were named H+-magadiite, H+-[Al]-magadiite and H+-[V]-magadiite. 2.2 Characterization X-ray diffractograms were obtained using a Shimadzu equipment, XRD 7000, with CuKα radiation source obtained with 40kV in filament and current of 30mA. Data were collected in the range of 1.5–55° 2θ with a scan speed of 2°min−1 at room temperature. The interplanar distances were calculated using Bragg’s Law (nλ =2dsin θ). The ICP–OES analyzes were performed using a Thermo Scientific iCAP 6000. Previously, the samples were thermally decomposed by heat treatment at 900°C for 10h in a furnace under dry oxygen atmosphere. Next, 100mg of these materials were digested in an acidic mixture of HF (48%) and HNO3 (65%) under microwave irradiation. The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) specific surface area was obtained by nitrogen adsorption using a Quantachrome Analysis at cryogenic temperature. The samples were heated at 100°C under vacuum for 15h prior to the measurement. The absorption spectra in the UV–vis region were obtained on a Cary Model 5000 spectrophotometer using a quartz cell. The spectra were recorded between 190–2500 nm without dilution of the sample. The background adopted was different for each catalyst: Na-magadiite was used for samples as synthesized and NH4 +-magadiite was used for the exchanged sample and H+-magadiite for calcined sample. The 27Al solid state nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectra were obtained on a Bruker Avance 400+ equipment with a frequency of 10kHz in a zirconia rotor, applying a single pulse of 1.5μs (π/12) duration and 2s delay time. Al(NO3)3 acid solution was used as reference and the High Power Decoupling (HPDEC) technique was applied. The Altd/Aloct ratios were obtained using the MasterC program. The TPD-NH3 measurements were carried out on a Quantachrome TPD/TPR ChemBet-3000 equipment. Approximately 100mg of H+-[Al]-magadiite were placed in a quartz reactor and treated for 2h at 300°C under flow of He (30mLmin−1). Then, the sample was cooled to 100°C and saturated with NH3/He (4vol%) for 2h; weakly bound ammonia was removed by He flow (30mLmin−1) for 1h. Finally, the sample was heated to 400°C at a heating rate of 10°Cmin−1 under flow of He and the release of ammonia was monitored using thermal conductivity detector. 2.3 In situ FTIR experiments These experiments were performed in order to study the catalytic conversion of ethanol over the samples synthesized in this work. In situ FTIR spectra were obtained at a resolution of 2cm−1 and a total of 128 scans using a Nicolet 6700 FTIR spectrometer. For carrying out this experiment, self-supporting pellets (thickness of 8.6mgcm−2 for NH4 +-magadiite, 7.5mgcm−2 for NH4 +-[Al]-magadiite and 7.0mgcm−2 for NH4 +-[V]-magadiite) were prepared and placed into an IR cell equipped with KBr windows and connected with a conventional high vaccum line (10−5 mbar). The NH4 +-[Al]- and NH4 +-[V]-magadiites were treated at 350°C in vacuum in order to remove water and ammonia, thus obtaining the acidic material and, successively, by heating at the same temperature in oxygen (300mbar) to remove carbonaceous impurities. After that, ethanol was added (P EtOH =3.1mbar) and spectra were collected from room temperature up to 350°C in static conditions. The gas phase in the cell was used as background and the spectra of the dry pellet was subtracted from all the spectra obtained from the pellet. The absorbance values were divided by the thickness of the pellet. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization 3.1.1 Long Range Structure The XRD patterns of the samples are displayed in Fig. 1 . Curves (a), (b) and (c) shows the characteristic peaks of magadiite [25] at 5.6° (1.55nm), 11.3° (0.77nm), 17.11° 2θ (0.52nm) corresponding to (001), (002) and (003) diffraction planes, respectively. In addition, peaks between 23 and 30° 2θ indicate the crystalline nature of the layer. These results confirm that the addition of aluminum or vanadium does not cause the appearance of contaminating phases or amorphization of the structure, as shown before [7,8,25]. Magadiite interlayer space changes according to the counter-ion and the amount of water present; sodium ion is easily exchanged and this process makes it possible to modify the acidity of this silicate [3,4]. For this purpose the samples were exchanged with NH4 + and the XRD patterns displayed in Fig. 1(curves (a), (b) and (c) compared with (d), (e) and (f)) shows that there was a displacement of the (001) diffraction toward slightly larger values of 2θ, indicating the reduction of the interlayer space from ca. 1.55nm to aproximately 1.36nm. These differences may be explained based on the size of hydrated radius of these ions, 0.358 and 0.331nm for Na+ and NH4 + [26], respectively. Thus, the size of hydrated NH4 + is about 8% smaller than the hydrated Na+, explaining the reduction of the basal spacing. It is also possible to observe that the region between 20° and 30° 2θ lost the usual resolution observed when the counterion is sodium. 3.1.2 Short-range structure The amount of aluminum and vanadium present in the solids are shown in Table 1 . [Al]-magadiite sample presents a larger amount of Al in comparison with the concentration in the synthesis gel. This is due to the higher solubility of silicon species, at the reaction pH (10.4–10.6), when compared to aluminum species. Surface area of these materials calcined at 450°C range from 76 to 269m2/g showing that indeed the active sites are accessible to the ethanol molecules. The 27Al MASNMR spectra of as-synthesized and NH4 +-exchanged magadiite and [Al]-magadiite are displayed in Fig. 2 . All spectra show signals around 57ppm which are assigned to the presence of aluminum in tetrahedral coordination in the structure [9,29]. Another peak is observed at 8ppm in Na- and NH4 +-[Al]-magadiite corresponding to octahedral aluminum [7,8]. Fig. 2a and b. These materials were exchanged with NH4Cl to remove any possible cationic aluminum species trapped in the interlayer space. The ratios between the areas of the peaks corresponding to the aluminum atoms into octahedral and tetrahedral coordination before and after NH4 + exchange enabled us to shed light on Al coordination. On Na-[Al]-magadiite Altd/Aloct was 0.65 and decreased to 0.58 after ion exchange. These results indicate that there is no cationic Al-species in this material [8]. The presence of octahedral Al is possibly due to partially extraframework Al ions in the form AlOH. When hydrated, these sites become octahedral Al sites, as shown before by Superti et al. [8]. The same analysis was performed with Na-magadiite (Fig. 2, curve (a)) and Na-[V]-magadiite (Fig. 2, curve (b)) and no Al peak was observed. The presence of aluminum in tetrahedral coordination is the first evidence that this material can exhibit Brønsted acidity and activity in acid catalysed reactions. As for vanadium (Table 1), it has been shown before [27,28] that the concentration of framework V can be very low, therefore the small amount of this heteroatom in [V]-magadiite is no surprise. The UV–vis spectroscopy, Fig. 3 , shows the sites where the metal can be found in this structure. There is abundant literature [28–32 and references therein] concerning the situation of V ions in silicate structures, a general agreement points to the existence of two sites for V in such structures: a more distorted one with four bonds to the structure (Fig. 4 a) and a less distorted site where one of the bonds bear an OH group (Fig. 4b). The absorption frequency of the energy charge transfer bands (O→V) for tetrahedral V5+ sites is related to the degree of distortion of the V5+ site, thus sites observed at ca. 210 and 238nm are the most distorted sites while the less distorted appear at 260–280nm. The band at 335nm is also assigned to tetrahedral framework V5+ but it seems to be related to the counterion in the structure [27,28]. Transitions around 400nm, corresponding to octahedral vanadium species are observed only for the acidic sample. Having these information in mind, it is possible to observe that samples NH4 +-[V]-magadiite. (Fig. 3, curve (a)) and H+-[V]-magadiite (Fig. 3, curve (b)) 3 present both more and less distorted V sites. 3.1.3 Acidity and catalytic conversion of ethanol The acidities of these materials were evaluated using the temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) of ammonia. Ammonia was adsorbed on the acid sites of the materials and removed by thermal desorption. The desorption temperature depends on the strength of the acid sites: weak sites desorb NH3 in the range from 150 to 250°C, moderate acid sites desorbs from 250 to 350°C and strong acid sites liberate ammonia from 350°C to 500°C [33,34]. Fig. 5 exhibits the NH3-TPD profile of [Al]-magadiite. It can be seen that H+-[Al]-magadiite exhibits a broad peak at around 200°C tailing in the direction of higher temperatures (Fig. 5a), an indication of the presence of weak to moderate acid sites in these samples. This result is a further indication that the inclusion of aluminum in the structure of magadiite generates acid sites, as discussed by 27Al MASNMR. The same experiment was performed with H+-magadiite and no signal was observed (Fig. 5b). 3.1.3.1 Catalytic conversion of ethanol: FTIR study The FTIR spectra of dehydrated, calcined, NH4 +-magadiite, NH4 +-[V]-magadiite and NH4 +-[Al]-magadiite are presented in Fig. 6 . The absence of the NH4 + characteristic band (3150cm−1) [35] indicates that this cation was completely removed. The samples exhibit two main bands in the range 3800–3400cm−1 [8,36–38]: a low intensity band at 3745cm−1, attributed to the presence of weakly acidic isolated silanol groups; this band is also observed in zeolitic structures [36,38,39] and a broad band centered at 3658cm−1 which is composite of two contributions: the bridging SiO(H)Al groups and OH silanol groups weakly perturbed due the interaction with other neighboring groups (Fig. 6, curve (b)) [8,40]. A shoulder is also observed at ca. 3470cm−1 on H+-magadiite and H+-[V]-magadiite and may be assigned to a portion of SiOH groups involved in the chain H-bonded in different configuration from that which originated the band at ca. 3650cm−1 and VOH groups, respectively. The band assigned to isolated silanols is more intense in H+-[Al]-magadiite (Fig. 6, curve (b)) and on H+-[V]-magadiite (Fig. 6, curve (c)) samples as heteroelement insertion into the framework creates silanol defects [8]. The catalytic activity of magadiite samples discussed above was investigated by ethanol conversion. Fig. 7 shows the spectra of 3.1mbar ethanol adsorbed on magadiite samples. Several modifications appear because of ethanol adsorption on the silicate and [Al]- or [V]- silicates. The first one is the displacement of the 3745cm−1 band on all samples (Fig. 7) to 3659cm−1, a 86cm−1 difference, typical of SiOH weak acidity. The 3659cm−1 band is wider in H+-[Al]- and H+-[V]-magadiite than in H+-magadiite (compare curve (a) with (b) and (c) on Fig. 7). This is probably due to diverse nature of SiOH groups in H+-[Al]- or H+-[V]-magadiite in comparison to H+-magadiite. Makarova et al. [41] showed in a very elegant work that both, increase in intensity and in width of bands corresponding to OH stretching vibrations upon base adsorption on zeolites and aluminophosphates, are in direct correlation with the bands displacement, in wavenumbers. The band displacement is approximately the same for the three samples in this work, however, the variation in width and intensity is different. This observation supports the idea of a band composite of different contributions especially in the case of H+-[Al]-magadiite, but also for H+-[V]-magadiite. It is important to comment that the negative band due to subtraction of the dry pellet was not observed in H+-[Al]-magadiite. That means that for H+-[Al]-magadiite, not all SiOH groups were accessible to ethanol molecules and thus the base line levels off on subtraction of the dry pellet. These non-accessible SiOH groups may exist due to two main reasons: difficulty of ethanol diffusion to the places where the sites are located or the ethanol interaction in not capable of displacing previously established interactions between SiOH groups. The introduction of ethanol on to the pellet causes also the displacement of the 3658cm−1 band to 3330cm−1, a difference of 328cm−1 much larger than the displacement observed when ethanol is adsorbed on SiOH groups. Again, although the maxima of this band is very close for all samples the band shown in the spectrum of the Al-sample is wider than the bands observed in the other two samples, probably as an effect of the ethanol interaction with several slightly different SiO(H)Al(or V) environments as also shown by a large peak on TPD-NH3. Again, the conclusions of Makarovás study [41], previously cited, apply to these bands. The heterogeneity of SiO(H)Al sites in H+-[Al]-magadiite was reported before in the literature [8]. The bands between 2975 and 2876cm−1 are due to CH stretching vibration of the adsorbed ethanol molecules [36]. After ethanol adsorption, the samples were heated at 100, 150, 200, 250, 300 and 350°C and remained at each of these temperatures for 1h. It is worth mentioning that all spectra were collected at room temperature. Fig. 8 shows the spectra of the solid surface (Fig. 8A) and gas phase (Figs. 8B–D) of the reaction performed on H+-[Al]-magadiite. Fig. 8A displays the species on the pellet after ethanol adsorption and heating at increasing temperatures. Right at 100°C it is possible to observe that a fraction of SiOH adsorbed ethanol molecules have desorbed: a negative band appears at 3745cm−1 accompanied by a wide band at 3340cm−1 probably due to the restoration of the extensive H-bonded SiOH groups in the solid. From 150°C to 250°C small variations were observed in the FTIR spectra. At 300°C, there is a sudden increase in the bands at ca. 3340cm−1 (νOH of acidic OH groups, ethanol and H2O) and in the region of 2900cm−1 due to CH stretching vibrations. At 350°C the negative band of free SiOH begins to disappear, indicating that the products of ethanol conversion adsorb on SiOH groups. The band appearing at 3676cm−1 is slowly displaced to 3643cm−1 suggesting that the species adsorbing on to SiOH groups are stronger bases than ethanol. Fig. 8B–D help to clear the nature of the species formed from ethanol. As for the pellet observed in Fig. 8A, hardly any difference can be observed in the gas phase of the cell from room temperature up to 250°C: the bands observed are typical of ethanol [42] (3675 νOH, 2800–3000 νCH, 1453 δCH, 1394 δOH, 1241 δCH, 1085–1048 and 880cm−1 (νC-O/νC-C). When the temperature arrives at 300°C, and after at 350°C, new bands appear at 3106 and 2988cm−1 (observed also for ethanol but in lower intensity) (Fig. 8B curves (f) and (g)) and at 949cm−1 (Fig. 8D): the first two assigned to ethylene CH stretching and the last CH2 wagging vibrations of ethylene [14,16]. The presence of water becomes evident at ca. 3360–3390cm−1 (Fig. 8B) and at 1640cm−1 (Fig. 8C) due to its production in Reaction (1). It is necessary to point out that liquid water and ethanol (at 1085, 1048 and 880cm−1, Fig. 8D) [42,43] were observed after the reaction at 300°C and 350°C. This is due to the formation of an aqueous ethanolic film on the windows of the FTIR cell. Besides these new bands in the gas phase, signals due to the presence of acetaldehyde were observed at 2735–2700cm−1 (Fig. 8B, curves (f) and (g)CH stretching vibration) and at 1760–1730cm−1 (νCO, Fig. 8C, curves f and g) [44,45]. The presence of this compound is not unexpected since it was also observed in the dehydrogenation of ethanol using dehydrated silica or silicalite-1 [21,22]. In these materials siloxane bridges were considered the active sites for ethanol dehydrogenation. The results of the ammonia desorption in NH4 +-magadiite discussed in the present work are in accordance with those observed for the highly dehydrated silica active in acetaldehyde production thus allowing to conclude that no effective acids sites are needed for the formation of acetaldehyde in the catalytic reaction, indicating that the oxygen bridge catalyzes it (Reaction 5). (5) C 2 H 5 OH+ ≡ Si −O −Si ≡ ⇄ ( ≡ Si −OH+Si −OCH 2 CH 3 ) → − ( ≡ Si −O −Si ≡ ) ≡ CH 3 CHO+H 2 Fig. 9 shows the results of H+-[V]-magadiite in the conversion of ethanol. The general appearance of these spectra points to the same behavior discussed for H+-[Al]-magadiite with slight but important differences. Analyzing the spectra on Fig. 9A, there is not the presence of water at higher temperatures, as observed in Sample H+-[Al]-magadiite (compare curves (f) and (g) in Fig. 8A with Fig. 9A and the band in 1640cm−1 in curves (f) and (g) in Fig. 8C with Fig. 9C). Ethanol is consumed in a more extensive way in H+-[V]-magadiite in comparison with H+-[Al]-magadiite, as shown by the comparison of curves (d)–(g) of Figs. 8A and E Figs. 9A in the region around 3000cm−1 in the pellet and in the gas phase on curves (f) and (g) of Fig. 8B and E Fig.9B. Also impressive is the difference in relative intensity of the bands at ca. 1400cm−1 in frames C of Figs. 8,9 and the bands at 1085, 1048 and 880cm−1 (νC-O/νC-C) in frames D of Figs. 8,9. These bands become more intense because these vibrations are sensitive to hydrogen bonding. Considering the bands corresponding to carbonyl groups in the range of 1760–1730cm−1, it is possible to conclude that acetaldehyde is produced in a more extensive fashion in H+-[V]-magadiite than in H+-[Al]-magadiite according to Reactions (3) and (5). Ethylene is also produced in H+-[V]-magadiite but in smaller amounts than in H+-[Al]-magadiite, the lower concentration of water, in the gas phase and in the pellet, indicates that reaction 1 is not the main responsible for ethanol consumption. Ethanol conversion to ethylene was also observed in H+-magadiite but in minute amounts (see Supplementary materials, Fig. S1). The possibility that ethanol dehydration to ethylene could occur in the absence of a catalyst was ruled out by performing the catalytic test in the IR cell in the absence of the silicate pellet; no product was observed. Summarizing, acid-metal-substituted magadiites are catalysts for ethanol conversion. Despite the variation in the properties of active sites in H+-[Al]-magadite [8], both acid and redox sites and the siloxane bridges produce acetaldehyde and ethylene at 350°C, in different concentration. 4 Conclusions It was shown that acid [Al]-and [V]-magadiite samples were prepared by the seed-induced crystallization method. The materials display weak to moderate acid sites capable of promoting ethanol conversion at temperatures of 300 and 350°C. It was shown here that ethanol can be converted to ethylene and acetaldehyde by acid [Al]- and [V]-magadiites. The larger activity of such solids in conversion to one or the other product is connected to the framework heteroelement: ethylene is largely produced by ethanol dehydration on H+-[Al]-magadiite while acetaldehyde can come either from ethanol oxidation catalyzed by siloxane bridges with production of H2 or by V-oxidizing sites in H+-[Al]-magadiite and H+-[V]-magadiite, respectively. As far as we could search, no works were published before where clay lamellar aluminosilicates were the acid catalysts. The majority of studies were performed on montmorillonite, a natural clay used for nitration and cyanotrimethylsylilation reactions. Having in mind that magadiite, contrarily to zeolites and molecular sieves, can have its interlayer spaces expanded and pillared, the success of ethanol conversion on H+-[Al]- and H+-[V]-magadiite shows that a set of weak-to-moderate acid-catalysed reactions can be performed on large sized molecules on an expandable layered material. The use of magadiite and other lamellar solids as catalysts bridges the gap between pure zeolitic systems, with reactions occurring in cages and channels, and silica or alumina with mainly catalytic active open surfaces. coredata.dc:description: In this work, aluminum- and vanadium-modified magadiites with Si/Al=15 and Si/V=33 molar ratios were obtained by Seed Induced Crystallization (SIC) method and the solid was investigated in relation to its acidity. The catalysts were characterized using X-ray diffraction (XRD), inductively coupled plasma–atomic emission spectrometry (ICP–OES), solid state magic angle spinning nuclear magnetic resonance (MAS-NMR), temperature-programmed desorption of ammonia (NH3-TPD) and Fourier transformed infrared spectroscopy in situ (FTIR). Crystalline [Al]-and [V]-magadiites were successfully obtained in which metal ions were inserted in the structure of the solid in tetrahedral coordination. The acidities of [M]-magadiites were used in catalytic ethanol conversion monitored by in situ FTIR: ethylene (949cm−1) and acetaldehyde (1760–1730cm−1) were the products obtained.
coredata.dc:title: Novel catalyst with layered structure: Metal substituted magadiite
